title: What Are Ethereum Layer 2 Blockchains and How Do They Work? - Ledger
summary: The article discusses the concept of Ethereum Layer 2 blockchains and their role in solving Ethereum's scalability issues. Ethereum is the second-largest blockchain network, but its popularity has led to network congestion and high transaction fees. Ethereum Layer 2 solutions are built on top of Ethereum and provide faster and cheaper transaction processing, while keeping the load on the parent chain minimal. There are different types of Ethereum Layer 2 blockchains, including sidechains and blockchain rollups, which have different mechanisms for reducing Ethereum's transaction load. Some popular Ethereum Layer 2 solutions include Polygon, Arbitrum, Base, ImmutableX, and Ronin. The article concludes that Ethereum Layer 2 networks can help make Ethereum more accessible and user-friendly, and that the Ledger ecosystem provides a convenient way to explore these networks.

title: Ethereum Once Looked Unstoppable. But It's 1 Crypto I'm Avoiding in 2024 - The Motley Fool
summary:
The article discusses how Ethereum, once considered unstoppable, has lost its momentum and is now facing competition from new and existing rivals. The author cites the recent strategic roadmap released by Ethereum, which lacks major changes and focuses on resolving design problems from The Merge, as a reason for concern. Additionally, the article notes that Ethereum's promised throughput speed of 1 million transactions per second has been scaled back to 100,000, while rival blockchain Solana already has the ability to handle 65,000 transactions per second.

The author also mentions that Ethereum's co-founder Vitalik Buterin is backing away from the "financialization" of the blockchain, which could impact its future growth prospects. Furthermore, the article highlights the rise of new competitors, such as Solana, Avalanche, and Cardano, which are growing faster than Ethereum and gaining traction in key blockchain niches.

To summarize, the article suggests that Ethereum's momentum has slowed down due to a lack of major changes in its strateg

title: Ethereum Validators Forced to Wait Days to Unstake Amid Celsius Withdraws - CoinDesk
summary: According to CoinDesk, Ethereum validators are facing delays of up to several days to unstake their ETH due to withdrawals by users on the Celsius network. This is a result of the Shapella upgrade in April, which enabled staked ETH withdrawals for the first time, but has led to longer lines of validators waiting to unstake their ETH. In April, there were over 28,000 validators waiting to leave the network after the upgrade, resulting in delays of up to 17 days for some validators to unstake their ETH.

title: Dencun and Pralectra: Ethereum core devs chart an ambitious 2024 - Blockworks
summary: The article discusses the plans and priorities of Ethereum's core developers for the next hard fork, which is expected to take place in late 2024 or early 2025. The developers are currently debating whether to focus on a feature-rich fork or a major protocol upgrade to introduce Verkle Trees to the execution layer. Verkle Trees are a new data structure that could help handle the long-term problem of "state bloat" as the network scales. However, there is no clear consensus on the call, with some developers advocating for keeping the focus squarely on Verkle Trees and others calling for a firm commitment to upgrade the network again in 2024. The article also mentions other potential features that could be included in the next upgrade, such as the EVM Object Format (EOF) and Execution layer triggerable exits (EIP-7002).

title: Ethereum validator exit queues spike as Celsius, Figment withdraw stakes - The Block
summary:
The article discusses a recent spike in validators queuing to withdraw their staked ether on the Ethereum blockchain. According to data from ValidatorQueue, the exit queue has reached 16,000, representing over 510,000 ether (worth $1.1 billion) with a maximum validator stake of 32 ether per validator. The processing time for completing the exit queue is estimated to be five days, with a total withdrawal length of over 14 days.

This development comes as Celsius, a staking provider that filed for bankruptcy protection last year, plans to cancel its stake in the Ethereum network and distribute assets to its creditors. Celsius' withdrawal request of over 200,000 ether ($450 million) has contributed to the heightened validator exit queue, although it's worth noting that not all of Figment's withdrawals are necessarily attributed to Celsius.

Additionally, the article mentions that the entry queue for new validators has remained close to zero, mirroring levels observed last week. The time to complete

title: Arbitrum surpasses Ethereum in daily decentralised exchange volume for first time - DLNews
summary: Arbitrum, a layer 2 blockchain, has surpassed the Ethereum mainnet in decentralized exchange (DEX) trading volume, with $1.8 billion in volume compared to Ethereum's $1.6 billion. This is the first time Arbitrum has surpassed the Ethereum mainnet in DEX volume. Additionally, Arbitrum's total value locked (TVL) has reached a new peak of $365 million, leading all layer 2 blockchains in net inflow of investor funds. However, Ethereum still leads in TVL with $705 million. Other layer 2 blockchains, such as ZkSync, have also experienced significant growth, with combined TVL of $20.7 billion, exceeding the TVL of all layer 1 networks except Ethereum. These developments suggest that layer 2 blockchains are contributing to the positive economic outcomes of Ethereum, including increased validator earnings and deflationary mechanisms.

title: Ethereum Layer-2 TVL hits $21b, reaching all-time high - crypto.news
summary: The total value of locked assets (TVL) in Ethereum (ETH) second-layer networks has reached a new high of over $21 billion, according to L2beat. This represents a 33% increase in TVL over the past month and a 333% increase over the past year. Arbitrum One remains the market leader with around $10 billion in TVL, followed by Optimism (OP Mainnet) with $5.8 billion. Other Tier 2 platforms have smaller TVLs. The growth in TVL on Ethereum layer-2 networks has been driven by increasing interest in decentralized finance (DeFi) and other use cases.

title: Arbitrum Surpasses Ethereum in DEX Volume - U.Today
summary: Arbitrum, a Layer-2 scaling solution, has surpassed Ethereum in terms of decentralized exchange (DEX) volume, with a 32.58% weekly increase in 24-hour trading volume to $1.83 billion. This has propelled Arbitrum to command 33.40% of the total DEX volume, dethroning Ethereum, which saw a 4.77% decrease in its 24-hour volume to $1.444 billion. The decentralized finance (DeFi) sector is witnessing a shift as Arbitrum leads the pack with a dominant presence in the DEX space, while Ethereum's dominance has reduced to 28.7% as of January. Other challenger protocols such as Solana, Binance Smart Chain (BSC), and Polygon are also gaining ground in the DEX ecosystem.

title: Ethereum staking exit queue hits record high amid Celsius unlocks - CryptoSlate
summary: The Ethereum network is experiencing a surge in validator exits, with a record high of over 16,000 validators in the exit queue as of January 5th, according to on-chain data. This has led to a significant increase in the wait time for unstaking, with an average of 5.6 days, and has raised concerns about the network's ability to handle large-scale exits. The majority of these exits are being driven by withdrawal requests from defunct CeFi lender Celsius Network and staking provider Figment, which together want to withdraw approximately 550,000 staked Ethereum. The situation has also led to a decrease in staking yield for Ethereum validators, with the current staking rewards reference rate at around 3.4%, down from nearly 8% in May 2023. The extended wait time for unstaking has also impacted the entry queue for new Ethereum validators, which remains low, hovering near zero.

title: Ethereum Price Crash Looming? Celsius To Unstake $465 Million ETH - NewsBTC

The company's decision to unstake a substantial amount of ETH is seen as a necessary step to ensure liquidity for creditor compensation.

According to blockchain analytics firm Nansen, Celsius possesses approximately one-third of the total ETH in the unstaking exit queue, which translates to a market value of around $465 million. To date, Celsius has already withdrawn over 40,000 ETH. The article also mentions that 352,000 ETH (54.7%) waiting to be withdrawn belongs to Figment, while 206,000 ETH (32%) belongs to Celsius.

Some investors have expressed concern that the release of such a large volume of tokens from st

title: Ethereum Validator Exit Leads to Backlogged Queue on Network - DailyCoin
summary: The article discusses an unexpected exodus of validators from the Ethereum network, leading to a backlogged queue on the network. Major players such as Celsius and Figment are triggering a significant withdrawal trend among validators, raising concerns about the future of the platform's Proof-of-Stake model. However, the churn limit, which controls both entry and exit queues, provides some reassurance. The declining staking yields have also been noted, but it is unclear whether this is a temporary blip or a sign of deeper systemic issues within the PoS network. The article concludes that the next few months will be crucial in understanding the long-term implications of this validator movement and whether it will lead to a more competitive landscape or deeper issues within the network.

title: High number of Ethereum blocks censoring US sanctioned users - Protos
summary:
According to a recent report, a significant percentage of Ethereum's blocks are censoring users who are on the US sanctions list. Data compiled by Labrys and Rated Network shows that approximately 42% of blocks since Ethereum's September 15, 2022 Merge from proof-of-work to proof-of-stake have sanctioned the wallets on the Specially Designated Nationals List. This means that relay operators are censoring transactions from these sanctioned users, which may include individuals or organizations under US sanctions.

The Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) maintains a list of sanctioned users, and Ethereum relays are required to censor wallet addresses on this list. This is different from permissionless crypto networks like Bitcoin, which allow any user to broadcast transactions for inclusion in an upcoming block.

The widely popular software MEV-Boost is used by many relay operators to censor sanctioned wallets by default. MEV-Boost also outsources validators' block production to a third-party marketplace, maximizing revenue through quantitative trading tactics

The rising DEX volume has also coincided with a sharp increase in the total value of assets locked on Arbitrum-based applications, which has increased by around $1 billion in the last six months to nearly $2.5 billion, with GMX, a decentralized spot and perpetual exchange, controlling

title: There’s Now a ‘Very Big Hole’ in Ethereum’s Value Proposition, Crypto Trader Warns – Here’s Why - The Daily Hodl
summary: The article discusses how interest in the Ethereum (ETH) ecosystem is declining as attention shifts to Bitcoin (BTC). A widely followed crypto analyst, Nicholas Merten, believes that future crypto development will likely focus on Bitcoin, which may diminish Ethereum's future value. Merten notes that there don't appear to be any new developments in the ETH ecosystem that are generating much excitement, and that Ethereum is losing out against Bitcoin in terms of growth and adoption. He also mentions that ETH/BTC is trading below the 200-week moving average, which is not a good sign. Merten concludes that there is a "very big hole in Ethereum's value proposition" and that investors may want to consider buying Bitcoin or other cryptocurrencies that are consistently outperforming it.

title: Solana Co-Founder: The Blockchain Doesn’t Need Layer-2s Like Ethereum - NewsBTC
summary: The article discusses the differing approaches of Solana and Ethereum in scaling their blockchains to handle the growing demand for decentralized applications (dApps). Solana co-founder Anatoly Yakovenko believes that the platform's hybrid consensus mechanism allows it to scale efficiently without relying on layer-2 solutions like those employed by Ethereum. Solana aims to synchronize a global atomic state machine as fast as the laws of physics allow, which Yakovenko believes makes layer-2 solutions unnecessary. In contrast, Ethereum is increasingly relying on layer-2 solutions to alleviate congestion and high transaction fees, with a combined total value locked (TVL) of over $20 billion on layer-2 solutions such as Optimism and Arbitrum. Solana has experienced instances of network freezes, which have raised questions about its reliability. In contrast, Ethereum has decided not to increase its gas limit further, which analysts interpret as a delay in on-chain scaling ambitions in favor of off-chain methods.

title: Ethereum Layer 2 Networks Just Set A New Record - NewsBTC
summary: According to data from L2BEAT, the total value locked (TVL) on Ethereum layer-2 networks has reached a new all-time high of $21.16 billion, representing a 340% growth from the same day last year. This growth is attributed to users flocking to layer 2 networks to escape high gas fees and congestion on the mainnet. Ethereum's TVL also witnessed steady growth throughout the year, adding $7.6 billion in the last quarter of 2023. However, Ethereum has seen a decline in daily active addresses and transaction count, with layer-2 chains processing more transactions than Ethereum itself. The article highlights the growth of Arbitrum One and OP Mainnet (formerly called Optimism) as the leading layer-2 scaling solutions, with Arbitrum One currently having $10.05 billion worth of cryptocurrencies locked and OP Mainnet having $5.84 billion.

This shift in volume is likely due to the upcoming Ethereum upgrade known as Dencun, which aims to scale Ethereum in a decentralized way. The upgrade includes EIP-4844, also known as proto-danksharding, which reduces the cost of posting large amounts of data to Ethereum and makes Layer-2 networks built atop Ethereum more cost-effective. Additionally, Arbitrum has been preparing for Arbitrum Orbit, a network of chains that share Optimism's open-source development stack. title: Celsius to unstake $470M Ethereum amid restructuring efforts, raising market concerns - CryptoSlate
summary: Celsius, a bankrupt crypto lender, plans to unstake approximately 206,300 Ethereum (ETH), worth around $470 million, as part of its restructuring efforts. This move has raised concerns in the crypto community, as it may increase selling pressure on the second-largest digital asset by market capitalization. Celsius has stated that the unstaking event will occur in the next few days and that eligible creditors will receive in-kind distributions of BTC and ETH as outlined in the approved plan. The decision has also led to a notable surge in the Ethereum validator exit queue, with over 16,000 validators waiting to exit the queue, a record high. The move signifies progress in Celsius's restructuring journey and the imminent return of customers' assets, with the court having approved a restructuring plan that could enable creditors to recover up to 79% of their holdings. However, customers are expressing weariness over the absence of a disclosed effective distribution date.

title: Solana Founder Names Biggest Threat to Ethereum - U.Today
summary:
The article discusses the potential threats to Ethereum and Solana, two prominent blockchain platforms. Anatoly Yakovenko, co-founder of Solana, identified the centralization of value in execution hotspots as the biggest threat to Ethereum. This risk arises if blockchain networks concentrate value capture in specific areas, contradicting Ethereum's decentralized nature. Yakovenko contrasted this with Solana's reliance on atomic composability, a foundational aspect of its design that enhances performance. However, he acknowledged that Solana's long-term success depends on the blockchain industry valuing atomic composability as highly as Solana does.

Another issue mentioned in the article is Ethereum's complex marketing and technical jargon, which could deter new developers. Ethereum's co-founder, Vitalik Buterin, agreed that simpler communication is necessary, particularly towards developers.

In summary, the article highlights the potential risks facing Ethereum and Solana, including centralization and messaging issues, and emphasizes the importance of atomic composability in Solana's design.

title: Celsius to Unstake Thousands of Ether, Possibly Easing ETH Selling Pressure - CoinDesk

title: Massive Ethereum Update Is Here: All You Need to Know About Prague - U.Today
summary:
The Ethereum network is set to undergo a major upgrade called the Prague upgrade, also known as the Pectra upgrade. This upgrade will bring significant improvements and changes to the platform, including the implementation of Verkle trees, a data structure that will optimize storage and access to information on Ethereum. However, there is a debate among developers about prioritizing the implementation of Verkle trees, with some advocating for a sole focus on this feature and others suggesting pursuing a smaller feature fork alongside Verkle development.

The core development team is currently testing the upgrade on several testnets, including Goerli, Sepolia, and Holesky, before rolling it out on the main network. The upgrade is expected to include various proposals to refine the Ethereum platform on different layers, such as precompiles for specific cryptographic operations, a new EVM object format (EOF), and modifications to smart contract capabilities.

The Prague upgrade is seen as a significant event that will shape the future of the Ethereum ecosystem, ensuring that the platform remains secure, efficient, and scalable for decentralized applications. While the implementation of Verkle trees is complex

title: ETF Analyst: Approval of Ethereum Spot ETF in US Could Happen This Year - Coinspeaker
summary: The article discusses the potential approval of an Ethereum spot exchange-traded fund (ETF) in the United States this year, following the approval of Bitcoin spot ETFs in October last year. According to an ETF and crypto analyst at Bloomberg, James Seyffart, the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has implicitly classified Ether as a commodity through its actions, which could pave the way for the approval of Ethereum spot ETFs. The SEC's approach to the cryptocurrency industry has been changed by the recent court win of Grayscale Investments against the SEC on the spot Bitcoin ETF ruling, which could lead to the approval of dozens of spot Bitcoin ETFs on Friday. The analyst believes that the SEC does not want to contradict its sister agency, the US Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC), which has already signaled that Ethereum is a commodity. The article also highlights the growth of the Ethereum ecosystem and its potential for further growth fueled by institutional investors,

title: Solana (SOL) Outperforms Ethereum (ETH) by This Overlooked Criterion, Analyst Says - U.Today
summary: The article discusses how Solana (SOL) is outperforming Ethereum (ETH) in terms of simplicity and ease of use for developers, according to analyst Qiao Wang. Wang suggests that Ethereum's (ETH) complex development and scaling narratives may be too difficult for average developers and entrepreneurs to understand, while Solana (SOL) has a clear and simple message of being the "fastest and cheapest" chain. The article also mentions that Ethereum's (ETH) focus on L2 solutions has been criticized by Cyber Capital CIO Justin Bons, who foresees a migration of focus to non-EVM blockchains like Near and MultiversX. Wang concludes that these issues can be fixed by removing mental friction and making Ethereum (ETH) more attractive for developers. Additionally, the article notes that Solana (SOL) has surpassed Ethereum (ETH) in various metrics such as weekly stablecoin transfers and decentralized exchange (DEX) usage.

title: Celsius to Unstake $466 Million Ethereum Holdings, 'Ensure Ample Liquidity' for Creditors - Decrypt
summary: Celsius Network, a bankrupt crypto lender, has announced that it will unstake its existing Ethereum holdings worth over $466 million to ensure ample liquidity when distributing assets to its creditors. The company has started the process of recalling and rebalancing assets in preparation for asset distributions, which will include between 67% and 85% of creditors' investments. Celsius accounts for 32% of ETH awaiting withdrawal, with approximately $2 billion worth of Bitcoin and Ethereum to be distributed among the firm's creditors. The company's former CEO Alex Mashinsky was arrested in July 2023 and indicted with seven charges including securities fraud, commodities fraud, and wire fraud. His trial is set for September 17, 2024.

title: Celsius Network to Unstake Ethereum for Asset Distribution amid Restructuring - Coinspeaker
summary:
Celsius Network, a bankrupt crypto lender, has announced plans to unstake a significant amount of Ethereum (ETH) to offset costs incurred during its restructuring process. The company has revealed that almost a third of the ETH in the pending withdrawal queue belongs to Celsius, totaling 206,300 ETH valued at approximately $468.5 million at current prices. This move is seen as a positive development for the Ethereum market in the long run, despite concerns about potential market impact due to a large sell-off.

Celsius Network has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in July 2022, following a liquidity crisis triggered by the volatile crypto market. The company has since outlined a scaled-back post-bankruptcy strategy focusing on Bitcoin mining, but this plan has faced skepticism from some creditors and regulatory hurdles still need to be cleared.

Meanwhile, the founder and former CEO of Celsius Alex Mashinsky is facing fraud charges and is currently out on bail. He is

title: Celsius Network Announces Unstaking of Ethereum Holdings to Facilitate Distribution to Creditors - Cryptonews
summary:
Celsius Network, a now-defunct cryptocurrency lender, has announced plans to unstake its Ethereum holdings to distribute assets to creditors. The company intends to unstake its ETH holdings to offset costs incurred during the restructuring process. Eligible creditors will receive in-kind distributions of BTC and ETH as outlined in the approved plan.

Celsius Network faced a liquidity crisis in July 2022 due to the downturn in the crypto market, leading to a freeze on withdrawals. The company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in the U.S. Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York. Since then, Celsius has been working towards a settlement plan that allows qualified users to withdraw 72.5% of their crypto holdings until February 28.

The company has also shifted its focus to crypto mining, with the creation of a public company dedicated solely to Bitcoin mining. Creditors will receive a portion of their recovery through shares in the upcoming Bitcoin mining company. This plan unlock

title: Ethereum suffered highest losses due to rug pulls and hacks, data shows - crypto.news
summary: According to a recent report by SlowMist, Ethereum suffered the highest losses due to rug pulls and hacks, amounting to $487 million in 2023. This is followed by Polygon, which lost $123 million. The report also found that decentralized finance (DeFi) was the most frequently targeted sector, accounting for 60.7% of the total incidents. The financial toll from these incidents amounted to $773 million, representing a significant decrease in losses compared to 2022. The report also highlighted that exit scams were the most prevalent cause of loss, accounting for 110 cases worth approximately $83 million.

title: Ethereum Mega Whales Continue To Buy: Do They Know Something You Don’t? - NewsBTC
summary: The article discusses the recent trends in Ethereum whale activity, specifically the rapid accumulation of ETH by the largest non-exchange wallets. According to on-chain analytics firm Santiment, the supply of ETH held by these top 150 self-custodial wallets has reached a new all-time high of 56.25 million ETH. This suggests that these large entities are bullish on the asset and are continuing to accumulate despite recent price fluctuations. In contrast, the supply of ETH held by top exchange wallets has remained low, which could be a positive sign for the long-term outlook of Ethereum. The article also notes that while Bitcoin has made some recovery, Ethereum has only rebounded slightly, with its price trading around $2,250. Overall, the article implies that the activity of Ethereum mega whales may be a positive indicator for the asset's price in the long term.

title: Celsius ETH Staking: Ethereum Validator Exit Queue Hits Record 16400 Amid Celsius' Unstaking Plans - CoinGape
summary: The article discusses the recent surge in the Ethereum (ETH) validator exit queue, which reached an all-time high of 16,400 amid Celsius' unstaking plans. Celsius, a bankrupt crypto lending platform, is recalling and rebalancing crypto assets, including ETH, to repay its creditors. According to Nansen data, nearly one-third of the ETH in the pending withdrawal queue is attributed to Celsius, with a value of approximately $467 million. The spike in validator exit queue has led to a wait time of over 5 days, with 19,906 validators awaiting a complete exit. The article also mentions that the recent move by Celsius has positive implications for customers who have been waiting for the return of their funds.

This suggests that holders may be selling their profitable positions to avoid further losses.

title: Ether (ETH): More Than Just a Cryptocurrency – The Fuel of the Ethereum Ecosystem - Punch Newspapers
summary:
The article discusses the role of Ether (ETH) in the Ethereum ecosystem, beyond its use as a simple cryptocurrency. ETH is the lifeblood of the Ethereum network, powering transactions, smart contract execution, and interactions within decentralized applications (dApps). It is the gas that powers the engine and the oil that keeps the gears turning, enabling the network to function.

The article highlights the various use cases of ETH, including:

1. Transactions: ETH is used to compensate miners for verifying and securing the network, with the transaction fee paid in ETH.
2. Smart Contract Execution: ETH is required to deploy and execute smart contracts, which power dApps. The complexity of the contract and the computational resources required determine the fee.
3. DApp Interaction: Most dApps require ETH for various functionalities within their ecosystems, such as playing blockchain games, trading on DeFi platforms, or buying NFTs.
4. Decentralized Finance (DeFi): ETH is used for borrowing, lending

title: Celsius Unstaked $470M Ethereum For Creditors Repayments - Crypto Times
summary: Celsius, a bankrupt cryptocurrency lender, has announced that it will unstake nearly $470 million worth of Ether (ETH) to prepare for repaying its creditors. The company has been focusing on restructuring since filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in July 2022 and has been working to unlock ETH to ensure timely distributions to creditors. According to Nansen, an onchain data provider and analytics firm, almost one-third of the total ETH in the withdrawal queue belongs to Celsius. The company has withdrawn 40,249 ETH so far and is waiting for 206,300 ETH to be withdrawn, which amounts to approximately $468.5 million. This unstaking activity is seen as positive news for Celsius' creditors, who have been waiting to be repaid for the past 18 months.

title: SEC Implicitly Recognizes Ether as Commodity, Paving Way for ETF - Cryptonews
summary: The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has implicitly recognized Ether (ETH) as a commodity, according to Bloomberg ETF analyst James Seyffart, paving the way for an Ethereum spot ETF to be approved in the US. This comes after the SEC approved Ethereum futures ETFs in August, which suggests that regulators may be more willing to list crypto products with a higher risk profile. The distinction between commodities and securities is important, as commodities are subject to different regulatory, tax, and reporting requirements. The Commodities and Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) has long considered both BTC and ETH to be commodities, while SEC chairman Gary Gensler has been tight-lipped about ETH's classification. However, the SEC excluded ETH from its lawsuits against Binance and Coinbase last year, which suggests that it may be treated as a commodity. The likelihood of Bitcoin spot ETF approval is high, with a 90% chance of approval early next week, according to Seyffart. While Ethere

title: Ethereum Developers Debate for Next Hard Fork After Dencun - Crypto Times
summary: The main Ethereum developers are discussing plans for a hard fork after the Dencun upgrade, which is proposed to take place in mid-March 2024. The main controversy is whether to prioritize a limited set of features or focus on a major protocol upgrade, Verkle Trees. Verkle Trees are seen as a solution to Ethereum's long-term state bloat problem, but implementing them is a complex process that may take 18 months or longer. Some developers, such as Guillaume Ballet of the Ethereum Foundation, argue for including Verkle Trees in the Prague-Electra (Pralectra) upgrade, while others, such as Lukasz Rozmej of Nethermind, suggest focusing on a feature-rich fork first to avoid delays. Potential features discussed include EVM Object Format (EOF) and Execution layer triggerable exits EIP-7002. The debate highlights the decentralized nature of the project, where progress can be slow and chaotic at times, but ultimately, the community will decide the direction forward.

title: Ethereum Name Service: V. Buterin Impels a 72% Increase - Cointribune EN
summary: Vitalik Buterin, co-founder of Ethereum, has called for the democratization of Ethereum Name Service (ENS), a platform that simplifies transactions by replacing complex addresses with ".eth" domain names. Buterin believes that Layer 2 networks such as Polygon and Optimism should utilize ENS to make it accessible and affordable for Ethereum network users. This has led to a 72% increase in the governance token of ENS, reaching its highest level in eight months. Buterin's endorsement has also positively impacted the price of ENS, which has stabilized at $12.9. The platform plays a crucial role in the Ethereum ecosystem and aligns with the principles of decentralization dear to the Ethereum community.

title: News Explorer — SEC 'Implicitly' Accepts ETH as Commodity, Paving Way for Spot Ethereum ETF: Bloomberg Analyst - Decrypt
summary: The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has "implicitly" accepted Ethereum (ETH) as a commodity, paving the way for the approval of spot Ethereum exchange-traded funds (ETFs), according to Bloomberg Intelligence analyst James Seyffart. The SEC's approval of Ethereum futures ETFs implies that ETH meets the criteria of a commodity, rather than a security, which could avoid legal challenges and potential unlisting of Ethereum futures ETFs. Seyffart expects to see potential Ethereum ETFs approved this year, with a final decision deadline in May 2024.

Therefore, it is essential to conduct independent research and only invest what you can afford to lose.

title: Celsius ends Ethereum staking rewards to pay back creditors - FinanceFeeds
summary: Celsius Network, a bankrupt crypto lender, has announced that it will stop staking its Ethereum holdings to generate liquidity and pay back its creditors. The decision comes as part of the company's ongoing restructuring process and aims to counterbalance the costs incurred during the bankruptcy. Celsius currently holds 32% of Ethereum awaiting withdrawal, valued at over $466 million. The company has allowed qualified users to withdraw 72.5% of their crypto holdings, with this opportunity available until February 28. A U.S. bankruptcy judge has given the green light to Celsius to shift its business focus to bitcoin mining. The company has also agreed to pay $4.7 billion in a settlement with the Federal Trade Commission, matching the approximate debt it owes to 1.7 million customers whose funds were frozen when the exchange ceased withdrawals last year. Meanwhile, the founder and former CEO of Celsius, Alex Mashinsky, has been arrested on fraud charges and is facing a jury trial on September 17. If found guilty, he

title: Celsius moves to unstake $470m in ETH for creditor repayments - crypto.news
summary: Celsius Network, a bankrupt cryptocurrency lender, has announced plans to unstake its existing Ethereum holdings worth $470 million to distribute to its creditors. The company aims to secure sufficient liquidity ahead of potential distribution of funds. Celsius has withdrawn 40,249 ETH to date, and 19,906 validators are awaiting complete withdrawal. The decision is seen as a positive development for customers who have been awaiting the return of their funds for over a year and a half. Celsius has also pivoted towards crypto mining operations, forming a new public company focused on Bitcoin mining with the approval of its creditors. The new company, MiningCo, is set to be managed by Hut 8 and will concentrate on staking and mining activities, with an anticipated balance sheet reaching $1.25 billion.
